doc.field: Agra Fort is one of the world heritage sites in Agra, also known as Red Fort for its walls of red bricks. A walled city, not fully accessible to the public, but what can be seen is impressive enough! We will go inside a little later, for now some views from outside. It is very nicely restored and more impressive than the fort of Delhi.

Agra Fort is one of the world heritage sites in Agra, also known as Red Fort for its walls of red bricks. A walled city, not fully accessible to the public, but what can be seen is impressive enough! We will go inside a little later, for now some views from outside. It is very nicely restored and more impressive than the fort of Delhi.

Agra Fort is one of the world heritage sites in Agra, also known as Red Fort for its walls of red bricks. A walled city, not fully accessible to the public, but what can be seen is impressive enough! We will go inside a little later, for now some views from outside. It is very nicely restored and more impressive than the fort of Delhi. And these nice guys to the left and right want to sell you something quite aggressively. It's like this at all tourist spots of India ... (Right outside the entrance, they are not allowed inside.)

Agra Fort is one of the world heritage sites in Agra, also known as Red Fort for its walls of red bricks. A walled city, not fully accessible to the public, but what can be seen is impressive enough! We will go inside a little later, for now some views from outside. It is very nicely restored and more impressive than the fort of Delhi.
red india fort agra vision:mountain059 vision:beach051

The famous Red Fort in Agra, India. Built by Shah Jahan, who had to spend the last years of life imprisoned here, after being dethroned by his son Aurangzeb. The Diwan-I-Am (Hall of public audience) built 1628 to 1635. Similar structures, also built under Shah Jahan, are in Delhi and Lahore.
The famous Red Fort in Agra, India. Built by Shah Jahan, who had to spend the last years of life imprisoned here, after being dethroned by his son Aurangzeb. The Diwan-I-Am (Hall of public audience).

More views of Agra's splendidly preserved Red Fort, where Mughal Shah Jahan was imprisoned by his own son with a view on his masterpiece, the Taj Mahal a bit downstream.
